utterances: Buried amid the transcripted e-mail exchange that former Florida Congressman Mark Foley allegedly carried out with an underage House page is a bit of dialogue that is every bit as chilling as their lurid sex talk.
It concerns the teen's mother, who apparently was at home in another room as the unnamed teen carried on a sexually explicit instant message conversation with Congressman Foley.
We don't know the identity of the teen or of his mother, and it is unclear if she has yet read the shocking instant message exchange between her son and the disgraced congressman.

What's as clear as day, though, is a sad, stark realization that some of our kids not only take advantage of their parents' relative technological ignorance but also that they see sporting good fun in outwitting us.
Between the lines of Foley's come-on is frightening evidence that Foley willingly exploited the gap between his young prey's Internet facility and the ignorance of the page's parents.
It is enough to make a mother unplug her children's desktop computers, cancel their cell phone accounts and delete forever their MySpace and Facebook profiles.
At the same time, we know that this mom versus the machine approach isn't the answer.

Yet for me and other moms who struggle to balance our children's growing tech savvy with our own ambivalence, this scandal is merely the latest vivid example of a paradoxical dynamic that keeps us up nights.
Even as we know our children will have to master this new technology for their future survival, we scramble to keep up.
For us it is a whiplash ride from optimistic tech cheerleader to vigilant cyber cop.
Last year, a New York Times reporter, Kurt Eichenwald, detailed the jaw-dropping story of a 13-year-old boy who used a Webcam to set up an online pornography business from his bedroom.
And in the past decade we've all read too many stories about young girls being lured to hotel rooms after engaging in sexually explicit conversations with adult men on the Internet.
And now the Internet enabled nature of the Foley revelations brings our low simmering mom versus the machine anxieties to a full boil.
For example, the unnamed teen in the widely circulated Foley e-mails expressed bemused resentment at his mother's lack of Internet facility.
At one point, according to the transcripts posted on ABCNews.com, the boy typed the peculiar Internet shorthand, BRB, to indicate a sudden need to step away from his computer.
BRB, he wrote, my mom is yelling.
The congressman answers, okay.
When the teen returns a few moments later writing simply, back.
Foley replies, cool, hope she didn't see anything.
The teen assures him that she hadn't and adds, she's computer dumb, though.
It makes me mad.
Foley laughs then asks why.
The teen writes, because she can't do anything.
She couldn't figure out how to download a file from an e-mail and open it.
Foley then typed, ha-ha.
And the teen adds, and she only does it like a million times a day.
Then in a turn of phrase that is quintessential teen speak, the page ended with, oh well, whatever.
Whatever indeed.

We may never learn the identity of the teen who carried out that exchange with Foley, but I'm guessing that after this, his mother and other moms who have read those transcripts will be taking a closer look at their children's Internet use.
(Soundbite of music)
Amy Alexander is an author and media critic living in Silver Spring, Maryland.
This is NPR News.
President Trump's Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh is defending himself against allegations of sexual misconduct.
In a highly unusual move, Kavanaugh and his wife, Ashley, sat down today for an interview with Fox News.
Here is part of what Brett Kavanaugh had to say.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
The truth is I've never sexually assaulted anyone in high school or otherwise.
I am not questioning and have not questioned that perhaps Dr. Ford at some point in her life was sexually assaulted by someone in some place.
But what I know is I've never sexually assaulted anyone.
As of now, President Trump and Senate GOP leaders are standing by Kavanaugh.
That is even after a new allegation of sexual misconduct surfaced last night in The New Yorker.
The magazine reports that a woman named Deborah Ramirez says Kavanaugh exposed himself to her during a drunken party at Yale when both attended college there in the 1980s.
NPR has not corroborated the claim, and Kavanaugh denies it.
NPR national political correspondent Mara Liasson joins me now.
Hey, Mara.
Hi, Mary Louise.
So how are Kavanaugh and the White House responding to these allegations?
Give me some more detail.
They're responding in the same way to both of them, which is to deny them.
Kavanaugh wrote a letter today to Senator Chuck Grassley, the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee.
He called the new allegation from The New Yorker and the old allegation from Christine Blasey Ford...
Ford.
...Smears, pure and simple.
He also went on Fox News, as you played a clip earlier.
And this was an extraordinary interview, very unusual.
He sat with his wife, and he said he wasn't going to withdraw his nomination.
Here's what he said.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
I'm not going to let false accusations drive us out of this process.

And we're looking for a fair process where I can be heard and defend the - my integrity, my lifelong record of promoting dignity and equality for women starting with the women who knew me when I was 14 years old.
I'm not going anywhere.
So clearly the White House is concerned.
They were concerned enough to put him out there I think in a first-ever pre-hearing interview like this.
And Donald Trump called the new allegations political.
Mitch McConnell said that Judge Kavanaugh is going to get a vote soon.
What I'm told by White House and Hill sources is they want to fight this.
They are determined to move forward with this nomination.
How might this second allegation, this second woman coming forward change that calculation, if at all?
I mean, the thinking has been that if more women came forward, this nomination becomes a harder fight.
Are you hearing anything from Republican circles that they are wavering on this?
NPR's Jack Speer reports.
Well, we just heard in Deborah Amos's piece three stories of Iraqi women fleeing their country.
They said they don't feel safe going home and they're not able to work or earn much money in Jordan or Syria.
So what are their options?
Very limited.
And this is one of the major concerns that we've got.
We're finding that Iraqis just do not want to return back.
And so what is your job there at the United Nations High Commission on Refugees?
What are your options in terms of placing them or getting them to places that are safe or in places where they like to live?
Well, the first thing is to try to identify those people who are most vulnerable.
And it's extremely difficult.
Many people just do not want to be identified.
They're afraid of being arrested.
They're being afraid of being deported back to Iraq.
And so one of our challenges is actually to go out, find those people who are in need of assistance, and provide assistance.
And that could be in the form of finance or access to health or education.
In many aspects it's easier to provide assistance to women in neighboring countries than what it would be for us to do such an assistance program inside Iraq.
And are you having any difficulties raising money for these refugees?
Are donor countries coming through with promised financial aid?
We put out an appeal for $261 million.
There's at least two million Iraqis outside the country and two million displaced inside the country.
But even that amount of assistance, which may seem relatively large, is insignificant compared to the total need.

Now, the United States admitted just 1,600 Iraqi refugees last year, and the State Department says it's hampered essentially by the need to conduct thorough background checks, post-9/11 background checks.
Last October, Ellen Sauerbrey from the State Department was on this program.
She told me things would speed up soon, and here she is.
Well, UNHCR has referred to our program about 12,000.
And of the 12,000, by the end of this calendar year we think we will have completed interviewing that entire initial group.
Andrew Harper of UNHCR, we are into the next calendar year, and do you know if those interviews were completed of the 12,000 that your agency referred?
Well, in regards to the numbers who entered the States, I think it was actually 2,600 who actually came in last year.
Our referrals actually to the States has been 16,000.
So at this point we've got U.S.
teams in Damascus and Amman who are working with us to move this backlog, as we might say.
The estimates that they're looking at moving in this year is about just over 12,000.
And is that enough?
UNHCR is estimating that there's probably about 80-100,000 Iraqis in need of resettlement.

One purpose of my mission to Washington this week has been to try and ensure that people don't forget about the other 90 percent of the Iraqis who will not be able to access resettlement and who will be in need of protection and assistance in the region.
So those 90 percent, what will happen to them?
We don't know.
We're providing some basic food items.
We're allowing the Iraqi children access to Syrian and Jordanian schools.
We've got access to medical care.
But the costs of living in these countries is much greater than the amount of financial assistance that we can provide.
So what we are doing is basically just delaying or providing token gestures for people before they step into abject poverty.
And then at that situation, what are their options?
They are to sell whatever assets they've got left, which declines by the day.
Are they forced to go back to Iraq because they've got no way to survive in Syria?
Or do they - the women start being forced into prostitution, the children start being forced into soliciting on the streets or not being able to go to school?
So it is a horrendous situation which unfortunately I think is only going to get worst.
We need to keep the humanitarian focus on those Iraqis who can't go back to Iraq.
Andrew Harper, thank you for joining us.
Thank you very much.
Andrew Harper is head of the United Nations High Commission on Refugees Iraq unit.
He joined us from Washington.
